Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Enabling Better Grid-Scale Energy Storage with Organic Additives
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will be to develop a more economical, scalable and sustainable type of battery for the renewable power grid. As wind and solar power generation become more common, economical energy storage is needed to supply power in the absence of wind or sun. Older battery technologies, such as lithium ion and lead acid batteries, pose challenges with supply, safety, longevity, and sustainability. This project will produce new chemical components to enable new grid-scale batteries based on safe, abundant, and recyclable zinc metal. The proposed batteries will last longer and run more efficiently to lower energy prices, reduce end-of-life costs, and accelerate the use of renewable energy. <br/><br/>This SBIR Phase I project proposes to produce chemical additives to improve the lifetime and efficiency of zinc-bromine batteries. These batteries pose challenges through unwanted side reactions occurring during battery charging. This project will develop new additives to prevent uneven zinc deposition and gas formation without sacrificing performance or adding significant cost. The research objectives include modification of currently available chemicals to achieve the desired performance, as well as to develop a suite of design principles for further improvements to battery additives. The proposed work is to validate the materials for long-term stability in harsh battery electrolytes and validate performance in suitable battery conditions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phase I of the NSF SBIR project "Enabling Better Grid-Scale Energy Storage with Organic Additives" was completed successfully. The primary goal of this project was to develop new additive chemicals that can improve the performance of Zinc-Bromine batteries for grid-scale electrical energy storage. Zinc-Bromine is a nonflammable, domestically made, safe, and sustainable alternative to lithium-based grid batteries. While they are very economically, strategically, and environmentally attractive, Zinc-Bromine batteries struggle with problems related to the internal deposition of Zinc metal when the battery recharges. In Phase I, this project sought to begin solving these issues by creating novel Zinc-controlling organic chemicals to act as additives in the battery electrolyte during charging.

Through the systematic study and design of hundreds of new chemicals over the course of twelve months this work produced many candidate molecules that can improve battery performance by preventing unwanted Zinc metal activity during charging. By allowing for smoother and more controlled Zinc deposition, these chemicals show strong promise to extend the operating lifetime of these batteries, improve energy density, and increase efficiency. Since each of these problems stem from suboptimal Zinc deposition inside the battery, the chemicals developed under this Phase I grant show excellent potential to improve them all. As planned, these chemicals were scaled-up to 100-gram quantities and sampled to Zinc-Bromine battery manufacturers during the middle of this Phase I work and many months ahead of schedule.

Zinc-Bromine batteries for grid-scale energy storage are an extremely promising option for US energy security and sustainability. The US houses the world's largest Zinc mine and is the second highest producer of Bromine so supply chains are favorable. These batteries are also nonflammable, long-lasting, and fully recyclable so they make sense for the large and future-facing power grid. With the goals of this Phase I SBIR grant met, and customer testing ongoing, this project will give this promising technology a significant boost in performance as it vies with less safe and less strategic lithium-based alternatives.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2021
Modified by: Onas J Bolton
